protocol.name: MDMA-Assisted Therapy for PTSD (MAPS Phase 3 Protocol)
protocol.overview: FDA-approved MDMA-assisted psychotherapy protocol based on MAPS Phase 3 trials (MAPP1 and MAPP2). Combines manualized trauma-focused therapy with 3 MDMA dosing sessions for treatment of PTSD. FDA granted Breakthrough Therapy designation and approved August 2024. Represents first FDA-approved psychedelic therapy.
evidence_sources: Mitchell JM, et al. Nat Med. 2021;27(6):1025-1033 (PMID: 33972795) - MAPP1 Trial
Mithoefer MC, et al. J Psychopharmacol. 2018;32(12):1295-1307 (PMID: 30179152)
Mithoefer MC, et al. J Psychopharmacol. 2019;33(1):16-24 (PMID: 30707853)
Jerome L, et al. J Psychopharmacol. 2020;34(2):145-156 (PMID: 31884849)
MAPS Public Benefit Corporation Phase 3 Protocol (NCT03537014, NCT04077437)
MAPS Therapy Training Manual for MDMA-Assisted Psychotherapy

steps.title: PTSD Diagnostic Assessment & Trauma History
steps.description: Comprehensive PTSD diagnostic evaluation using gold-standard CAPS-5 interview to confirm diagnosis, assess symptom severity, characterize trauma history, and establish baseline.

caps_5_interview.name: Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale for DSM-5 (CAPS-5)
caps_5_interview.description: Gold-standard structured interview for PTSD diagnosis and severity
caps_5_interview.administered_by: Trained clinician/rater (separate from therapy team to reduce bias)
caps_5_interview.scoring: 0-80 scale; severity ratings for each symptom cluster
symptom_clusters: Negative alterations in cognition and mood

trauma_history_assessment: Other traumatic events (childhood abuse, combat, assault, accidents, etc.)
Current trauma triggers and avoidance patterns

inclusion_criteria.prior_treatment: At least one prior evidence-based trauma treatment (PE, CPT, EMDR) with inadequate response (per MAPS protocol)
inclusion_criteria.capacity: Able to provide informed consent and participate in therapy

documentation_requirements.trauma_narrative: Detailed account of index trauma and other significant traumas
documentation_requirements.symptom_timeline: Onset, course, and fluctuations in PTSD symptoms
treatment_history: Reasons for treatment failure or inadequate response
functional_impairment: Impact on self-care and daily functioning

steps.title: Medical & Psychiatric Screening
steps.description: Comprehensive medical and psychiatric evaluation to identify contraindications, ensure cardiovascular safety, screen for comorbidities, and assess suicide risk.

vitals_monitoring.cardiovascular_focus: MDMA causes transient increases in BP and HR; baseline cardiovascular health essential

lab_tests_required: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) - liver and kidney function
Pregnancy test (for women of childbearing potential)
HIV test (if risk factors - MDMA can affect immune function)

cardiovascular_assessment.critical_importance: MDMA causes dose-dependent increases in BP (20-30 mmHg) and HR (20-30 bpm) acutely
ecg_evaluation: Rule out arrhythmias, conduction delays, ischemia
QTc interval < 450 ms (QT prolongation is relative contraindication)
No signs of structural heart disease
blood_pressure_criteria: History of hypertension acceptable if well-controlled on medication

common_comorbidities: Major depressive disorder (very common with PTSD, not exclusionary)
exclusionary_conditions: Borderline personality disorder (relative contraindication - requires careful consideration)
Active suicidal ideation with intent and plan

substance_use_disorders: Active moderate-severe SUD is exclusionary (except tobacco, caffeine)
Past SUD with ≥ 6 months sobriety acceptable
prior_mdma_use: Not exclusionary (many PTSD patients have self-medicated with MDMA)
Important to assess prior responses (positive or negative)
Document quantity, frequency, and context of use

criteria: Active suicidal ideation with intent and plan is exclusionary
Passive suicidal ideation or history of attempts without current intent is not exclusionary
Safety plan must be in place before enrollment

steps.title: Safety & Eligibility Determination
steps.description: Comprehensive review of all screening data to determine patient eligibility based on MAPS protocol inclusion/exclusion criteria.

absolute_contraindications.criteria: Uncontrolled hypertension (BP >140/90), recent MI (<6 months), unstable angina, significant arrhythmia, heart failure
absolute_contraindications.rationale: MDMA acutely increases BP and HR; too risky

absolute_contraindications.criteria: Current or past schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, or psychotic disorder
History of seizures (except childhood febrile seizures)
Cirrhosis, hepatic failure, significantly elevated LFTs
absolute_contraindications.rationale: MDMA metabolized by liver; risk of toxicity

absolute_contraindications.criteria: Currently pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding
absolute_contraindications.rationale: Safety not established; potential neurotoxicity to fetus
Substance use may interfere with therapy; risk of MDMA misuse

absolute_contraindications.criteria: Current suicidal ideation with intent and plan
absolute_contraindications.rationale: Requires higher level of care; safety risk

relative_contraindications.management: Carefully evaluate capacity for therapeutic relationship, emotional regulation, and safety; may proceed with enhanced support
Significant dissociation may complicate MDMA sessions; assess capacity to remain present; specialized training needed
Ensure excellent BP control, have rescue medications available, enhanced monitoring during sessions
Passive ideation okay; establish safety plan; close monitoring

medication_contraindications.rationale: Risk of serotonin syndrome, hypertensive crisis

medication_contraindications.action: Must taper and discontinue; washout ≥ 5 half-lives before MDMA (typically 2-4 weeks)
medication_contraindications.rationale: SSRIs block MDMA effects (diminish therapeutic response); some serotonin syndrome risk

medication_contraindications.action: Discontinue with psychiatric oversight; adequate washout
medication_contraindications.rationale: May increase seizure risk with MDMA

medication_contraindications.action: Typically need to discontinue (are usually prescribed for conditions that exclude patient)
medication_contraindications.rationale: May block MDMA effects; patient likely has exclusionary diagnosis

medication_contraindications.action: Taper and discontinue if possible; low-dose PRN acceptable
medication_contraindications.rationale: May diminish MDMA therapeutic effects; available as rescue medication during sessions

medication_contraindications.action: Continue if for essential hypertension control
medication_contraindications.rationale: Needed for cardiovascular safety; may slightly blunt MDMA effects

branch_outcomes.description: Patient meets all criteria, no contraindications, ready for preparation phase
Eligible after tapering SSRIs or other interfering medications
Absolute contraindication present, refer to alternative PTSD treatments

steps.title: Preparation Session 1 - Therapeutic Alliance & Education
steps.description: First of three 90-minute preparation sessions focused on establishing therapeutic alliance, educating about MDMA-assisted therapy, and beginning trauma processing in preparation for MDMA sessions.

therapist_team_structure.model: Co-therapist dyad (two therapists work together throughout protocol)
therapist_team_structure.composition: Often male-female dyad to represent diversity and provide balanced perspectives
roles: Both therapists present for all preparation, MDMA, and integration sessions
Shared responsibility for holding safe therapeutic container
Non-directive, supportive presence during MDMA sessions
Active trauma-focused work during preparation and integration
therapist_team_structure.training: MAPS-certified MDMA therapy training (120+ hours didactic + supervised practice)

rapport_building: Introduction to both therapists and their backgrounds
Patient sharing story, trauma history, and PTSD impact
Establishing trust and safety in therapeutic relationship
Addressing any concerns or fears about treatment
education_about_mdma: Pharmacology of MDMA (serotonin, dopamine, oxytocin release)
Expected psychological effects (empathy, openness, reduced fear, increased self-compassion)
Physical effects (increased HR/BP, jaw clenching, sweating, pupil dilation, nausea)
Timeline: onset (30-45 min), peak (2-3 hours), descent (3-4 hours), return (6-8 hours)
Safety of therapeutic MDMA vs. street ecstasy (pure, measured dose, medical monitoring)
Difference from recreational use (therapeutic setting, trauma-focused intention)
Research findings (efficacy, safety profile, FDA approval)
therapy_framework_introduction: Inner healing intelligence principle (trust body's innate wisdom)
Non-directive approach during MDMA sessions (therapists follow patient's process)
Importance of staying present with difficult emotions/memories
Use of music to support emotional processing
Physical touch only with consent (e.g., holding hand if patient requests support)
trauma_processing_begins: Identifying specific traumatic memories to work with
Exploring PTSD symptoms and their origins
Beginning to approach trauma material in safe, titrated way
Not full exposure therapy, but gentle engagement
safety_and_boundaries: Consent for any physical touch during MDMA sessions
Permission to express anything without judgment
Therapists' role as non-directive guides, not directors

core_principles: Non-directive: Follow patient's inner process, don't impose agenda
Inner healing intelligence: Trust patient's psyche to guide healing
Unconditional positive regard: Accept all experiences without judgment
Presence: Be fully present with whatever arises
Safety: Hold container of safety for difficult material to emerge
therapist_guidelines: Reflect and validate rather than interpret
Support patient going toward difficult material, not avoiding
Minimal intervention during peak MDMA effects

steps.title: Preparation Session 2 - Deepening Trauma Work
steps.description: Second preparation session continuing trauma processing, deepening therapeutic relationship, and further preparing for MDMA experience.

trauma_exploration: Exploring specific traumatic memories in more detail
Identifying triggers, flashbacks, and avoidance patterns
Processing emotions related to trauma (guilt, shame, anger, grief)
Cognitive processing (beliefs about self, world, safety)
Beginning to build capacity to stay present with trauma material
mdma_session_preparation: Discussing intentions for first MDMA session
What do you hope to work on?
Fears or concerns about MDMA experience?
somatic_awareness: Noticing where trauma is held in body

steps.title: Preparation Session 3 - Final Preparation
steps.description: Third and final preparation session before first MDMA session. Final trauma processing, intention setting, and practical preparation for MDMA day.

final_trauma_processing: Any remaining trauma material to explore before MDMA session
Identifying specific memories or themes to work with during MDMA
Building confidence in ability to stay present with difficulty
intention_setting: What do you need to face or release?
Balancing specific intentions with openness to what emerges
practical_preparation: Review of MDMA session timeline and structure
What to eat (light breakfast, NPO 4 hours before)
Clear schedule for day of and day after
informed_consent_review: Re-confirm understanding of MDMA effects, risks, benefits
Consent to proceed with MDMA dosing
therapeutic_relationship_check: Feeling safe and trusting of therapy team?

steps.title: MDMA Dose Determination
steps.description: Clinical decision-making to determine MDMA dose based on MAPS protocol, patient factors, and safety considerations.

maps_dosing_protocol.supplemental_dose: 40-60 mg (half of initial dose) given 1.5-2 hours after initial dose
maps_dosing_protocol.standard_protocol: 120 mg initial + 60 mg supplemental (most common in Phase 3 trials)

dose_selection_factors.consideration: MAPS used fixed dosing (not mg/kg), but weight is consideration

dose_selection_factors.naive: Standard dose 120+60 mg (naivety not a reason to reduce)
dose_selection_factors.experienced: Standard dose; tolerance unlikely if abstinent

dose_selection_factors.high_anxiety: Some clinicians start lower (80-100 mg) for highly anxious patients, but MAPS protocol used standard dosing

dose_selection_factors.older_adults: May use lower end (80-100 mg) for age >60, though MAPS trials capped at 65

session_2_and_3_dosing.approach: Can adjust based on Session 1 response
session_2_and_3_dosing.if_session_1_insufficient_effect: Increase initial dose to 120 mg (if was lower) or maintain
session_2_and_3_dosing.typical: Most patients receive same dose for all 3 sessions

branch_outcomes.description: MAPS standard: 120 mg initial + 60 mg supplemental
Conservative dosing: 80 mg + 40 mg for smaller/anxious/cautious patients

steps.title: MDMA Session 1 - First Experimental Session
steps.description: Full-day MDMA-assisted therapy session (8-10 hours). Administration of MDMA in safe therapeutic setting with continuous psychological support and medical monitoring. Trauma processing facilitated by MDMA's empathogenic and fear-reducing effects.

activities: Brief check-in (how are you feeling, sleep, readiness)

baseline_assessments.vitals: Blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, weight
baseline_assessments.psychological: Brief mood and anxiety check, suicidal ideation screening
baseline_assessments.medical_clearance: Physician confirms patient medically stable for MDMA

pre_session_procedures.informed_consent: Final confirmation of consent to proceed

room_setup: Futon or daybed with pillows and blankets
sensory_elements: Curated music playlist (6-8 hours) - key therapeutic element
session_environment.therapist_positioning: Both therapists seated near patient, attentive but not intrusive

mdma_administration.initial_dose: 80-120 mg MDMA hydrochloride in gelatin capsule

supplemental_dose.timing: 1.5 to 2 hours after initial dose (typically when effects peaking)
supplemental_dose.rationale: Extends therapeutic window without excessive peak intensity
supplemental_dose.patient_choice: Patient can decline supplemental dose if desired

onset_phase.patient_experience: Gradual onset; possible initial anxiety, nausea, temperature changes; beginning to feel effects
therapist_actions: Calm, supportive presence
Encourage patient to lie back, use eyeshades, listen to music
Reassurance if anxiety arises
Minimal talking - allow patient to turn inward
Check-ins: 'How are you feeling?'
onset_phase.vitals: Blood pressure, heart rate, temperature at T+30 min

ascent_phase.patient_experience: Effects intensifying; increased empathy, openness, reduced fear; trauma material may begin emerging
therapist_actions: Continue non-directive presence
If patient speaks, listen attentively and reflect
Gentle encouragement to stay with whatever arises
Do not direct toward specific content - follow patient's process
Music continues as primary guide
ascent_phase.vitals: BP, HR, temp at T+60 min and T+90 min

peak_phase.timeframe: T+90 to T+240 minutes (1.5 to 4 hours)
peak_phase.patient_experience: Peak MDMA effects; profound empathy, self-compassion, ability to approach trauma without overwhelming fear; trauma processing often happens here; emotional release, insights, reframing
therapist_actions: Remain quietly present, both therapists in room
Non-directive support - patient leads content
Active listening if patient sharing trauma material
Reflection, validation, gentle questions: 'What's that like for you?', 'What do you need right now?'
Support emotional expression (crying, anger, grief) without judgment
Encourage staying present: 'Stay with it', 'You're safe'
Physical comfort if requested (hand holding, tissue, blanket)
Somatic awareness: 'Where do you feel that in your body?'
Respect silence - not all moments need words
peak_phase.vitals: BP, HR, temp every 60 minutes (T+120, T+180, T+240)

typical_patterns: Revisiting traumatic memories with reduced fear
Somatic release of trauma held in body
therapist_facilitation: Encourage staying with memory/emotion rather than avoiding
Provide grounding if patient becomes overwhelmed (but trust process)
Minimal interpretation - let patient derive own meaning

descent_phase.timeframe: T+240 to T+360 minutes (4 to 6 hours)
descent_phase.patient_experience: MDMA effects gradually diminishing; integration beginning; may feel peaceful, tired, emotionally open
therapist_actions: Continue supportive presence
Begin gentle check-ins and integration conversation
What stands out from your experience?
Encourage patient to express insights or realizations
Help patient begin making sense of experience
Support any continued emotional processing
descent_phase.vitals: BP, HR, temp at T+300 and T+360

return_and_integration.timeframe: T+360 to T+480 minutes (6 to 8 hours)
return_and_integration.patient_experience: Mostly returned to baseline; reflective, often peaceful; emotionally tender
therapist_actions: Integration conversation about session
What did you learn or realize?
How do you feel about the trauma now?
What shifted or changed?
Normalizing tiredness and emotional openness
Encouragement and affirmation of work done
Preparing for evening and next day
return_and_integration.vitals: Final BP, HR, temp before discharge
discharge_criteria: Safe transportation home with responsible adult

vitals_monitoring.frequency: Every 30-60 minutes throughout session, more frequent if concerns

alert_parameters.action_if_abnormal: Physician evaluation, consider rescue medications, possible session interruption

vitals_monitoring.typical_mdma_effects: BP increase 20-30 mmHg, HR increase 20-30 bpm, temp increase 0.5-1°C - monitor but expected

benzodiazepine.indication: Severe anxiety, panic, or hypertension not responding to reassurance
benzodiazepine.note: Use sparingly - may interfere with therapeutic process

antihypertensive.medication: Labetalol 10-20 mg IV or nifedipine 10 mg SL
antihypertensive.indication: Severe hypertension (SBP >200 or DBP >120) or symptomatic

antiemetic.note: Can give prophylactically if patient prone to nausea

evening_instructions: Rest at home with trusted person present overnight
Early bedtime (MDMA can interfere with sleep initially)
Contact emergency number if any concerns
common_post_session_experiences: Some patients feel mild 'comedown' (low mood, fatigue) days 2-5 - normalize and reassure
post_session_care.next_day: Integration session scheduled (typically 10-11 AM following morning)

steps.title: Integration Session 1 - Day After MDMA Session 1
steps.description: Critical integration session occurring morning after MDMA session to process experience, capture insights, solidify trauma processing, and address emotional responses.

check_in: How do you feel this morning (physically, emotionally)?
experience_review: Open invitation to share about MDMA session
Timeline of experience - what happened when
Challenging moments and how they were navigated
trauma_processing_integration: How do you feel about the trauma now compared to before?
Any shifts in perspective or understanding?
Beliefs about self, safety, or world that changed?
Shame, guilt, or self-blame - any movement?
insight_consolidation: What did you learn or realize?
Connections between trauma and current symptoms?
Parts of yourself that you reconnected with?
emotional_processing: Supporting continued emotional expression if needed
somatic_integration: Any shifts in where you hold trauma in body?

clinical_monitoring.ptsd_symptoms: Brief check on current PTSD symptoms - any immediate changes?
clinical_monitoring.adverse_effects: Any concerning psychological or physical effects

homework: Continue journaling about experience and insights
Noticing any shifts in PTSD symptoms, triggers, or avoidance
Staying connected to insights from session

steps.title: Integration Sessions 2-3 (Weeks Following MDMA 1)
steps.description: Two additional integration sessions in weeks following first MDMA session to continue processing trauma, consolidate gains, and prepare for second MDMA session.
session_focus: Continued trauma processing building on MDMA session
Deepening insights and realizations from MDMA experience
Addressing trauma material that emerged or remains
Preparing for second MDMA session - what still needs to be addressed?
steps.typical_timeline: Week 2 and Week 3-4 after MDMA Session 1

clinical_monitoring.ptsd_trajectory: Are symptoms improving, stable, or worsening?

steps.title: MDMA Session 2 - Second Experimental Session
steps.description: Second full-day MDMA session, typically 3-5 weeks after Session 1. Same protocol structure, deepening trauma processing and consolidating therapeutic gains.

session_notes.timing: Typically 3-5 weeks after first MDMA session (per MAPS protocol)
session_notes.dose: Same as Session 1 unless adjustment indicated (typically 120 mg + 60 mg)
session_notes.structure: Identical to Session 1 (same timeline, monitoring, therapeutic approach)
focus: Often deeper trauma processing in second session
Building on work from first session
Addressing trauma material that wasn't fully processed first time
Many patients report second session is most profound
common_patterns: Reduced anxiety going into session (know what to expect)
Deeper trust in therapists and process
Ability to go further into traumatic material
More somatic release and emotional expression

steps.same_day_integration: Brief integration at end of session
steps.next_day_integration: Integration session scheduled for following morning

steps.title: Integration Sessions After MDMA 2 (3 sessions)
steps.description: Three integration sessions in weeks following second MDMA session. Continued trauma processing, symptom monitoring, and preparation for third session.
session_focus: Comparing first and second sessions - patterns or differences
Functional improvement - returning to avoided situations

steps.title: MDMA Session 3 - Third and Final Experimental Session
steps.description: Third and final MDMA session, typically 3-5 weeks after Session 2 (around Week 9-10 of protocol). Consolidation of trauma processing and therapeutic gains.

session_notes.timing: Typically 3-5 weeks after second MDMA session
session_notes.dose: Same as prior sessions unless adjustment indicated
focus: Integration of all three MDMA experiences
Often sense of completion or closure
Preparing for life without continued MDMA sessions
common_patterns: Third session often feels integrative rather than opening new material
Reconnection with parts of self lost to trauma
Hope and readiness to move forward

steps.title: Integration Sessions After MDMA 3 (3 sessions)
steps.description: Three final integration sessions following third MDMA session. Focus shifts to consolidating gains, relapse prevention, and preparing for treatment termination.
session_focus: Reflection on entire treatment experience (all 3 MDMA sessions)
PTSD symptom review - comparing to baseline
Functional improvement - work, relationships, quality of life
Preparing for termination of MAPS protocol

clinical_monitoring.symptom_tracking: PTSD symptoms compared to baseline and mid-treatment
clinical_monitoring.safety: Ongoing suicidal ideation screening, substance use

steps.title: End of Treatment CAPS-5 Assessment (Week 18)
steps.description: Comprehensive CAPS-5 assessment by independent rater at Week 18 (primary endpoint) to evaluate PTSD symptom change from baseline. This is the primary outcome measure for FDA approval.

caps_5_interview.administered_by: Independent rater (blind to treatment condition in trials; not therapy team to reduce bias)
caps_5_interview.purpose: Assess PTSD symptom severity at end of treatment
caps_5_interview.primary_outcome: Change in CAPS-5 total score from baseline to Week 18

response_and_remission_criteria.response: CAPS-5 score reduction ≥ 10 points from baseline OR loss of PTSD diagnosis
response_and_remission_criteria.remission: No longer meets CAPS-5 criteria for PTSD (score typically <20)

maps_phase_3_results.mapp1_trial: 71% of MDMA group no longer met PTSD criteria vs. 48% placebo (with therapy)
maps_phase_3_results.mapp2_trial: 86% of MDMA group achieved clinically significant benefit

steps.title: Final Therapy Session & Termination Planning
steps.description: Final session with therapy team to review outcomes, celebrate progress, plan for ongoing care, and say goodbye to therapeutic relationship.

outcome_review: Review CAPS-5 results and clinical assessment
What changed, what remains to work on
reflection_on_treatment: What was learned about self, trauma, healing
How MDMA sessions contributed to healing

if_in_remission: Early warning signs of PTSD symptom return
Ongoing therapy recommendation (continued processing, life transitions)
Possible booster MDMA session in future if needed (6-12 months)
if_partial_response: Possible additional MDMA sessions (per protocol or off-label)
if_non_response: Alternative treatments (different trauma therapy, medications, intensive programs)

termination_processing: Processing ending of this intense therapeutic relationship
Acknowledging patient's courage and hard work

twelve_months_post_treatment.purpose: Long-term outcome evaluation (MAPS trials tracked to 12 months)
twelve_months_post_treatment.maps_findings: Most patients maintained improvement at 12-month follow-up

booster_sessions.indication: PTSD symptom re-emergence after initial response
booster_sessions.timing: Not before 6 months after final MDMA session
booster_sessions.protocol: 1-2 preparation sessions + MDMA session + integration sessions
booster_sessions.evidence: Some patients benefit from occasional booster sessions; individualized decision

absolute_contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension or significant cardiovascular disease

adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Monitor closely, rescue medications if severe
Magnesium supplementation, jaw massage, mouth guard
adverse_effects_monitoring.duration: During session and potentially 1-2 days after
During onset and peak, usually resolves
During and several hours after session

adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Normalize, reassure, self-care, usually mild and self-limiting
Expected, sleep hygiene, may offer short-acting sleep aid

adverse_effects_monitoring.frequency: Occasional (10-20%) - trauma processing can temporarily increase symptoms
adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Increased support, integration therapy, normalize as part of healing
adverse_effects_monitoring.duration: Days to weeks, typically improves with integration

adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Monitor LFTs at baseline and if concerns; dose reduction or discontinuation

adverse_effects_monitoring.frequency: Very rare (requires combination with serotonergic drugs)
adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Medication washout pre-treatment, avoid combining with SSRIs/MAOIs

neurotoxicity_concerns.background: High-dose, frequent recreational MDMA use associated with serotonergic neurotoxicity in animal studies
neurotoxicity_concerns.therapeutic_dosing: Limited evidence of neurotoxicity with 3 therapeutic sessions at moderate doses
neurotoxicity_concerns.maps_findings: No evidence of cognitive decline or neurotoxicity in Phase 2/3 trials
neurotoxicity_concerns.monitoring: Cognitive function assessed pre/post treatment; no impairment found

abuse_potential.risk: MDMA has abuse potential (Schedule I/Class A)
abuse_potential.therapeutic_context: Very low abuse risk in controlled therapeutic setting with trauma focus
abuse_potential.maps_trials: No cases of MDMA abuse or misuse in trials
abuse_potential.safeguards: Limited number of sessions, no take-home MDMA, therapeutic container

considerations: Childhood trauma, developmental trauma, repeated trauma
May require more sessions or ongoing therapy
Strong therapeutic relationship essential
May have more dissociation - therapist training important
MAPS trials included complex PTSD - effective
Very common with PTSD (not exclusionary)
MDMA therapy often improves depression along with PTSD
Monitor mood throughout treatment
May need antidepressant washout pre-MDMA
Combat trauma common indication
May have complex/repeated trauma, moral injury
Strong evidence of benefit in veteran populations
Culturally sensitive approach important
VA and DOD exploring MDMA therapy implementation
Trauma-informed, gender-sensitive approach essential
Therapy team gender composition may matter (patient choice)
Consent and boundaries particularly important
Strong evidence of benefit for sexual trauma PTSD
May have complex trauma, shame, dissociation
Repeated trauma exposure, critical incidents
Occupational stigma around mental health treatment
Peer support important
MAPS trials included first responders successfully

maps_certification.required: MAPS-certified MDMA therapy training for therapists conducting FDA-approved treatment
components: Experiential learning (some programs include therapist's own psychedelic experience)
Understanding of trauma, PTSD, psychedelic pharmacology, inner healing intelligence model

core_competencies: Ability to hold space without imposing agenda

clinical_pearls: Therapeutic relationship is foundation - invest in preparation phase
Non-directive approach during MDMA sessions allows patient's inner healing intelligence to guide
Music is a key therapeutic element - carefully curated playlists guide emotional journey
MDMA creates window of optimal arousal - not too numb, not too overwhelmed - to approach trauma
Integration therapy is where healing is consolidated - MDMA opens door, therapy walks through it
Three sessions is protocol standard, but some patients benefit from more or fewer
Safety screening is paramount - cardiovascular and psychiatric contraindications must be respected
Mid-week 'comedown' is common and self-limiting - normalize and support patients through it
Trauma processing can temporarily increase symptoms - part of healing, not treatment failure
Most patients maintain gains long-term (12+ months) - durable treatment for chronic PTSD
FDA approval makes this first-line option for treatment-resistant PTSD
Co-therapy dyad provides safety, support, and balanced perspectives throughout treatment
